posts.name: Matt Soucy (he/him)
posts.cooked:
FRC Team 166, the Chop Shop, would like to announce the return of our Code Review Party.

After the Interruption in 2020 put a stop to all competitions, we thought it would be a fun idea to have teams learn from each other another way. I have since received requests to bring back the Code Review Party, so we‚Äôre happy to do so. Team code releases are good practice, but largely interactive and one-way - the Code Review Party is meant to be bidirectional, so that teams can receive feedback on their code.

Each team that signs up will be given another team‚Äôs code to examine and provide feedback. We ask that teams be respectful, and be looking for ways that both they and the teams that they review can learn and grow their software for the future. We will be connecting teams based on language, to help teams get the most benefit.

To sign up, fill out the form HERE .

Rules:

Registration will be open until 6/28/2025, at which point we will match up teams.

Reviewing is an open-ended task, but we request that teams have reviews finished by 8/30/2025. This will allow teams to incorporate the feedback in their code for offseason competitions and future training.

If we get enough teams signed up, we would like to give each team several other teams to review, to improve exposure to other concepts.

Helpful feedback only - things like ‚Äúuse this language instead‚Äù are not helpful, most teams have a reason to use their chosen language.

Feel free to ask questions!

Reviews should be conducted via repository issues. This will help reduce the number of places to check for feedback. Suggestion is to have a single central issue, use a checklist for minor comments, and separate linked issues for major comments.

By signing up, your team agrees to make their code open to review, and agrees to review the code of the team(s) they are given.

link_counts.title: Change one letter of a thread title

Registration will be open until 6/28/ 2020

posts.cooked: This is what I get for starting with the 2020 CRP‚Äôs post‚Ä¶ Nice catch! Dates are fixed to be 2025

posts.name: Brad
posts.cooked: This sounds great.   I need to get with my students to see who will be a designated reviewer.  If someone doesn‚Äôt sign up can they still review?  Otherwise I will put myself as a reviewer and see who i can get by june to do the review.

posts.name: Ben
posts.cooked: Would teams that use specific languages only be partnered with other teams with that language? Ex: I only know java. Would I still get c++ and Labview repositories or would I only get Java?

posts.name: Matt Soucy (he/him)
posts.cooked: Yes, teams will be partnered with other teams based on the language of their code. Based on FIRST ‚Äôs reported language use, most teams will probably be using Java, but I‚Äôll check each submission just to be safe.

posts.name: Matt Soucy (he/him)
posts.cooked: Any number of people from your team can review code, even if they don‚Äôt sign up on the form - the reviewer list on the form is mainly to make sure that there‚Äôs a point of contact. In fact, I‚Äôm going to request that if you have more than three reviewers (awesome!) then please don‚Äôt submit the form more than once just so you can list them all.
Are ftc teams also welcome to join the party? would love to get feedback on our code

posts.name: Matt Soucy (he/him)
posts.cooked:
I don‚Äôt believe this question came up last time! I want to say yes, however I‚Äôm concerned that the code will be very different from FRC code, since WPIlib hasn‚Äôt unified the two competitions yet. So I‚Äôd say that if you want to register, you‚Äôre welcome to, but be warned that you might get feedback that‚Äôs more FRC -oriented. If multiple FTC teams register then I‚Äôll try to pair them up as best as I can.

(Is your profile picture a Lego Perry the Platypus? Nice!)

amazing than I will register

(Is your profile picture a Lego Perry the Platypus? Nice!)

thanks I got bored while mentoring one of my FLL teams and that what came out

posts.name: Matt Soucy (he/him)
posts.cooked:
We currently have thirteen teams signed up! Almost all of them use Java as their language, although there‚Äôs some additional Kotlin and Python.

Registration is still open until 6/28/2025 (I got the date right this time!), so there‚Äôs time to join in!

posts.name: Matt Soucy (he/him)
posts.cooked: We are now up to sixteen teams! Reminder that signups close in eight days , at which point I‚Äôll assign teams for review

posts.name: Matt Soucy (he/him)
posts.cooked: I am sending out the assignments now, from a mcrbnh.com email address. If you don‚Äôt receive one in the next few days, then check your spam folder and send a message here.
